page.title: Metropolitan Zoological Park and Museum District

revision.text:
The '''Metropolitan Zoological Park and Museum District''' or '''ZMD''' is a cultural tax district in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis City]] and [[St. Louis County, Missouri]]. The district has five subdistricts, these being the [[St. Louis Art Museum]], [[St. Louis Zoo]], [[St. Louis Science Center]], [[Missouri History Museum]], and [[Missouri Botanical Garden]]. Of these, all but the Botanical Gardens are located in or near [[Forest Park (St. Louis)|Forest Park]]. The subsidies provided by the district ensures that the institutions are public non-profits with free admission for all, with the exception of the Botanical Gardens, which charges a nominal admission fee.
==History== In the early 1960s, the St. Louis Art Museum and the St. Louis Zoo were both publicly funded by a tax in St. Louis City. Zoo chairman [[Howard Baer]] and his successor, Circuit Judge [[Thomas F. McGuire]], worked with their supporters to secure the statute to establish the district. H.B. 23 authorized a 1969 vote in St. Louis City and County, where voters approved the creation of the tax district to fund the Zoo and Art Museum at a rate of 8 cents for every $100 assessed. The Science Center, which had previously received no tax benefit, was added at a rate of 4 cents for every $100 assessed.<ref name=mzdstl>{{cite web |url=http://www.mzdstl.org/History.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125165028/http://www.mzdstl.org/History.htm |archivedate=2010-01-25 |df= }}</ref>
[[Earl Wipfler]] was selected as the first Executive Director of the district in 1972, and he guided the initial creation of the district's budgeting and accounting procedures. The [[Missouri Supreme Court]] approved them.<ref name=mzdstl/> Wipfler served as Executive Director until 1990.
The Missouri Botanical Garden was added as the district's fourth subdistrict in 1983, and the History Museum in 1988.<ref name=mzdstl/>
[[Olney F. Otto]] served as the district's second executive director from 1990 until his death in 2001. [[Mr. J. Patrick Dougherty]] has served in the position since.<ref name=mzdstl/>
==Revenue== From an initial annual revenue of $3.9 million in 1972, the district grew to $72 million in 2008. In the past few years, around 85% of these funds have come from the county with the city providing only about 15%. Though the tax is the same in both places, the disparity in income and population accounts for the difference in money generated.<ref name=index>{{cite web |url=http://www.mzdstl.org/index.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091207114623/http://www.mzdstl.org/index.htm |archivedate=2009-12-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Governing Board== The eight-member governing board is composed of four appointments from St. Louis City, chosen by the mayor, and four from St. Louis County, chosen by the county executive. The terms last four years, and two positions open up on January 1 each year, one for the city and one for the county.<ref name=mzdstl/>
==Criticism== {{POV-section|date=February 2015}} {{Unreferenced-section|date=November 2016}} Through the government subsidy, all five subdistricts are able to operate without charging admission. Some people have questioned whether tourists and residents of areas outside St. Louis City and St. Louis County should continue to be allowed free admission, and that it might be just to charge them, as they contribute nothing to the regional attractions. The exception to this is the Missouri Botanical Garden, which charges admission to non-residents of St. Louis City and County at double the rate of residents. Institutional and political efforts to persuade neighboring [[Jefferson County, Missouri|Jefferson]], [[St. Charles County, Missouri|St. Charles]] and other counties to pass tax levies to join the district (and contribute to operations of the regional attractions) have not been successful. The issue of equity has come up intermittently throughout the district's history.
==Emulation== The MZMD is one of the earliest, largest, and most successful cultural districts of its kind. Other cities have created similar programs and tax districts based on the St. Louis model.<ref name=index/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.mzdstl.org/index.htm District Website]

{{lead too long|date=October 2018}} [[File:Moving panorama.jpg|thumb|right|400px|1848 illustration of a moving panorama designed by [[John Banvard]].]]
The '''moving panorama''' was a relative, more in concept than design, to [[panoramic painting]], but proved to be more durable than its fixed and immense cousin. In the mid-nineteenth century, the moving panorama was among the most popular forms of entertainment in the world, with hundreds of panoramas constantly on tour in the [[United Kingdom]], the [[United States]], and many European countries. Moving panoramas were often seen in melodramatic plays. It became a new visual element to theatre and helped incorporate a more realistic quality. Not only was it a special effect on stage, but it also served as an ancestor and platform to early cinema.
The word “panorama” is derived from the Greek words “to see” and “all.” [[Robert Barker (artist)|Robert Barker]], an Irish-born scene painter, coined the term with his first panorama of Edinburgh, displayed in a specially built rotunda in Leicester Square in 1791. This attraction was extremely popular amongst the middle and lower classes for the way it was able to offer the illusion of transport for the viewer to a completely different location that they had most likely never seen.
Panoramic paintings and the various offshoots had become so in demand across Europe and America by the early nineteenth century that the enormous paintings had begun to be displayed in less specialized settings, like community halls, churches, and eventually theaters where they evolved into moving panoramas and became essential to theatrical set design. Moving panoramas were achieved by taking the long, continuous painted canvas scene and rolling each end around two large spool-type mechanisms that could be turned, causing the canvas to scroll across the back of a stage, often behind a stationary scenic piece or object like a boat, horse, or vehicle, to create the illusion of movement and travelling through space. The immense spools were scrolled past the audience behind a cut-out drop-scene or [[proscenium]] which hid the mechanism from public view. [[Robert Fulton]] obtained a patent for the panorama in 1799 in [[France]]; he is credited with helping create the spool mechanisms that allowed for the moving panorama to take hold in theatrical set design, combining the technology of the [[Industrial Revolution]] and art for profit, very much a nineteenth century idea.
However, these paintings were not true [[panorama]]s, but rather contiguous views of passing scenery, as if seen from a boat or a train window. Unlike panoramic painting, the moving panorama almost always had a narrator, styled as its "Delineator" or "Professor", who described the scenes as they passed and added to the drama of the events depicted. One of the most successful of these delineators was [[John Banvard]], whose panorama of a trip up (and down) the [[Mississippi River]] had such a successful world tour that the profits enabled him to build an immense mansion, lampooned as "Banvard's Folly", built on [[Long Island]] in imitation of [[Windsor Castle]]. In Britain, showmen such as the durable [[Moses Gompertz]] toured the provinces with a variety of such panoramas from the 1850s until well into the 1880s.
These moving panoramas were readily accepted in New York, where Americans loved the melodramatic genre of plays, which made use of the newest technologies and relied on spectacle. William Dunlap, America’s first theatre historian, professional playwright, and a painter himself, was commissioned by the Bowery Theatre in New York in 1827 to write, somewhat reluctantly, ''A Trip to Niagara: or Travellers in America: A Farce'', a satirical social comedy, specifically for an already existing painting of a steamboat journey up the Hudson River to the base of Niagara Falls, named the “Eidophusikon.” The production was extremely popular, not for the play, but for the spectacular moving scenery.
The concept of early cinema, “moving pictures,” is a direct evolution of the concept of a moving panorama. The first use of the scrolling background concept early on in film was rear projection. This technique, for example, was used when stationary actors were filming in a car that wasn’t actually moving, but instead had a projection of changing locales behind on the rear window to create the illusion that the car was moving, a trope often used in Hitchcock movies. Today, we have much more realistic computer technology to create this illusion of movement, but the image of a stationary object or actor in front of a changing background harkens back to the moving panorama scroll. Moving projections of clouds or passing objects on cycloramas at the back of a stage sometimes seen in modern live theater productions also utilize the illusion of seamless movement behind a stationary object that was popularized by the moving panorama of the nineteenth century.
== Popular subjects == Moving panoramas (or sometimes moving [[diorama]]s) often recreated grand ceremonies. In [[Philadelphia]] in 1811 nearly {{convert|1300|ft|m}} of painted cloth were unwound to display the [[Federal Procession of 1788]],<ref>{{cite book|ISBN=1558492038|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O1u4d_XeZZ0C|first=Len|last=Travers|title=Celebrating the Fourth: Independence Day & the Rites of Nationalism in the Early Republic|publisher=[[University of Massachusetts]]|year=1997}}</ref> and [[George IV#Reign|George IV's coronation]] in London was treated as a "Grand Historical Peristrephic Panorama" by the Marshall brothers.<ref>peristrephic means "panoramic, unfolding" ([[Oxford English Dictionary|OED]])</ref>
Exotic landscapes and travel were popular themes, particularly trips to [[India]], [[New Zealand]], and the Arctic regions. Popular subjects in America were of river journeys, such as in Dunlap’s ''Trip to Niagara'', and trips out west following the railroads that were quickly springing up as America expanded. [[John Banvard|Banvard]]'s enormous [[Mississippi River]] panorama was shown on both sides of the [[Atlantic]] and a moving panorama of "Romantic and Picturesque Scenery in the Environs of [[Hobart]] Town" taken to London in 1839 allowed people in England to get an impression of [[Australia]].<ref>[http://www.acmi.net.au/AIC/PECK_BIO.html Australian Centre for the Moving Image] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901013133/http://www.acmi.net.au/AIC/PECK_BIO.html |date=2007-09-01 }}</ref> A narrator explained the scenes passing in front of the audience and music played. In the [[United States]], moving panoramas were popular throughout the 1850s and 1860s, with multiple touring shows operated by proprietors such as Edwin Beale, T.K. Treadwell, [[Henry Lewis (artist)|Henry Lewis]] and George K. Goodwin. Among the more popular subjects were the Arctic regions, major cities such as [[New York City|New York]], the [[Mississippi River]] and [[Niagara Falls]].
[[Peter Grain (artist)|Peter Grain]]'s ''Panorama of the Hudson and James Rivers - Scenes in Virginia'', painted in oil and watercolor, was exhibited at the San Francisco Hall in [[San Francisco]] in March 1853, concluding a tour of cities across the United States. The work covered 9,400 feet of canvas.
==Poole's Myriorama== [[Image:Myriorama 1891.jpg|thumb|250px|left|1891 poster for Poole's Myriorama featuring the [[Emin Pasha Relief Expedition|meeting]] between [[Henry Morton Stanley|Stanley]] and [[Emin Pasha]]]] In the early nineteenth century, [[United Kingdom|British]] traveling panorama shows had been operated by several firms, among them the Marshall brothers of [[Glasgow]] and J.B. Laidlaw. However, it was not until the 1850s that a nearly year-round programme of such shows was offered by [[Moses Gompertz]], who with his assistants the Poole brothers traveled the length and breadth of Britain. Gompertz continued in this line of work through the mid-1880s, when his business was taken over by the Pooles. To distinguish theirs from rival shows, they started to use the name ''Myriorama'' which seems to have originated around 1824 with the [[Myriorama (cards)|toy]] of that name despite suggestions that it was coined by Joseph Poole in about 1883.<ref>{{cite book|last=Huhtamo|first=Erkki|title=Illusions in Motion: Media Archaeology of the Moving Panorama and Related Spectacles|year=2013|isbn=978-0262018517|page=292|url=http://mitpress.mit.edu/authors/erkki-huhtamo}} This says :''The word "Myriorama" was introduced around 1883 by Joseph Poole, who defined it: "If we prefix ''horama'' with the Greek ''myriroi'', which signifies "various", we arrive at the latest development of this class of entertainment, 'Myriorama' meaning "to view various scenes and objects."''</ref> By 1900 they had seven separate shows touring for 40 weeks of the year.<ref>''[[The Scotsman]]'' obituary of Jim Poole, 21 January 1998</ref> They added elaborate effects to the scrolling paint-and-cloth panoramas: cut-out figures moving across the scene, accompanied by music, lighting and sound effects. The narrator, often one of the Poole brothers in [[:wikt:evening dress|evening dress]], would describe and interpret. "Poole's Myriorama" was well-known and is even mentioned in [[James Joyce]]'s ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]''.
Stories of travel and adventure, often military adventure, were popular: the action was conveyed by hidden stagehands moving shaped [[Flats (theatre)|flats]] across a fixed backdrop. One naval battle had them manoeuvring ships accompanied by gunshot noises, puffs of smoke and ''[[Rule Britannia]]'' with waves on a rippling cloth at the front of the stage.<ref>{{cite book|isbn=1857252047|title=Auld Reekie: An Edinburgh Anthology|editor=Ralph Lownie|publisher=Timewell Press|year=2004}}</ref> Some shows, with [[Variety show|variety]] acts as well as myriorama displays, employed dozens of people.
Some of the first films seen in the UK were presented in late 19th century myriorama shows.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/ulas/downloads/savoy.pdf |title=Richard Buckley and Heidi Addison, ''An Historic Building Record of the former Cannon Cinema, Abington Square, Northampton'' (2001) |access-date=2007-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060924042128/http://www.le.ac.uk/ulas/downloads/savoy.pdf |archive-date=2006-09-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Although [[Film|cinema]] eventually replaced the myriorama, this kind of entertainment stayed popular until the late 1920s, and was considered a Christmas-time treat. In December 1912 the Pooles first presented their ''Loss of the Titanic'' in "eight tableaux", starting with "a splendid marine effect" of the ship gliding across the scene.<ref>{{cite book|isbn=1903000009|first=Stephen|last=Bottomore|title=The Titanic and Silent Cinema|publisher=The Projection Box|year=2000|pages=191}}</ref> A descendant of theirs, Hudson John Powell, gathered together the family story in ''Poole's Myriorama!: a story of travelling panorama showmen'' (2002). ''[[The Guardian]]'' has called their myrioramas part of the "popular visual culture of the 19th century".<ref>''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 January 1998</ref>
The last of the Poole family who were in the Myriorama business was John Reginald Poole (1882 - 1950). His father Charles William Poole had taken over all the family's entertainment concerns. In 1937, he published the book One Hundred Years of Showmanship This is available in digitised version from the Bill Douglas Collection, held by Exeter University <ref>{{cite web|url=https://collections.exeter.ac.uk/repository/handle/10472/183|title=One Hundred Years of Showmanship: Poole's 1837-1937|date=23 June 2009|website=Collections.exeter.ac.uk|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref>
===Fuller's Myriorama=== [[Image:Fuller's Myriorama.jpg|thumb|150px|right|Poster for Fuller's Myriorama show about [[Ireland]]]] A Myriorama company formed in New Zealand in 1896 by [[John Fuller (singer)|John Fuller]] (1850–1923) used [[magic lantern]] images rather than paintings wound on rollers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnzb.govt.nz/dnzb/default.asp?Find_Quick.asp?PersonEssay=2F29|title=Online Dictionary of NZ Biography|website=Dnzb.govt.nz|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> Their shows offered a changing display of pictures accompanied by commentary and music.
==Surviving moving panoramas== [[Image:Garibaldi panorama scene25.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Scene 25 from the Garibaldi Panorama ([[Brown University]])]] Few moving panoramas have survived to this day, and conservation issues prevent them from being shown in their original format. The most notable rediscovered moving panorama in the [[United States]] is the [[Grand Moving Panorama of Pilgrim's Progress]], which was found in storage at the [[York Institute]], now the Saco Museum, in [[Saco, Maine]] by its former curator Tom Hardiman. It was found to incorporate designs by many of the leading painters of its day, including [[Jasper Francis Cropsey]], [[Frederic Edwin Church]], and [[Henry Courtney Selous]] (Selous was the in-house painter for the original Barker panorama in London for many years). Another significant panorama, Russell and Purrington's "Whaling Voyage 'Round the World," is in the collection of the [[New Bedford Whaling Museum]] and it is currently on exhibit during conservation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whalingmuseum.org/explore/collections/panorama|title=Purrington-Russell Panorama Conservation Project - New Bedford Whaling Museum|first=New Bedford Whaling|last=Museum|website=Whalingmuseum.org|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> [[C.C.A. Christensen]]'s "Mormon Panorama" survives at [[Brigham Young University]]'s Museum of Art, where it has been the subject of several recent shows and lectures.
Another moving panorama was donated to the Anne S. K. Brown Military Collection at the [[Brown University Library]] in 2005. Painted in [[Nottingham]], England around 1860 by John James Story (d. 1900), it depicts the life and career of the great Italian patriot, [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]] (1807–1882). The panorama stands about 4½ feet high and approximately {{convert|140|ft|m}} long, painted on both sides in watercolor. Numerous battles and other dramatic events in his life are depicted in 42 scenes, and the original handwritten narration survives. A section of The Moving Panorama of Texas and California (1851-1852), titled "[http://www.thestoryoftexas.com/discover/artifacts/independence-hall-at-washington-on-the-brazos Independence Hall at Washington-on-the-Brazos]" is on display at the [[Bullock Texas State History Museum]] in Austin, Texas. This panorama was commissioned by Levi Sala, and painted by Charles L. Smith. The panorama made its public debut at the Dan Rice Amphitheater on St. Charles Street in New Orleans on May 1, 1852. The scenes were painted by Charles L. Smith from drawings and sketches provided by James G. Benton of sites of historical interest in Texas, including scenes along the Brazos River from San Felipe to Washington-on-the-Brazos, as well as views of the San Antonio Missions and episodes of the Texas Revolution of 1835-1836. Also, a member of the Mier Expedition, Charles McLaughlin, contributed eyewitness sketches of the 1842 Texas incursion into Mexico. An artist known only as Mr. Perrine would supply drawings of the California gold country.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Painting in Texas: The Nineteenth Century|last = Pinckney|first = Pauline|publisher = University of Texas Press|year = 1967|isbn = 9780292736825|location = Austin, TX|pages = 68–69}}</ref>
==Crankies== '''Crankies''' are moving panoramas on a smaller scale, with a typical example being roughly twenty feet long by eighteen inches high. Like the larger moving panorama, a crankie is typically displayed with live music or narration. In the form of crankies, the moving panorama has experienced a revival in the United States since the mid-2010s.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Colson |first1=Nicole S. |title=Crankie Revival is Nod to Theatrical History |url=http://www.sentinelsource.com/elf/crankie-revival-is-nod-to-theatrical-history/article_d98ba022-f7a1-11e7-964c-f773e4fa01e4.html |accessdate=13 August 2018 |work=SentinelSource.com |publisher=[[The Keene Sentinel]] |date=12 January 2018 |ref=KeenSentinel}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Sullivan |first1=Robert |title=What Can an Old Folk Song Tell Us? |url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/what-can-an-old-folk-song-tell-us |accessdate=13 August 2018|publisher=[[The New Yorker]] |date=17 March 2018 |ref=NewYorker}}</ref>

[[File:Toha_Khana_(Kachari_bari)_Complex_of_Shah_Suja_19.jpg|thumb|Tahakhana complex]] '''Mughal Tahakhana''' ''or'' '''Shah Shuja Tahakhana''' is a three storied building known as ''Tahakhana''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shibganj.chapainawabganj.gov.bd/upazilla_tourist_spot |title=উপজেলার দর্শনীয় স্থান | Shibganj Upazilla | শিবগঞ্জ উপজেলা |website=Shibganj.chapainawabganj.gov.bd |date= |accessdate=16 March 2017}}</ref> ''({{lang-bn|তাহখানা}}, [[Persian Language|Persian]]: تاهخانا {{IPAc-en|ˌ|t|ɑː|h|ɑː|k|ɑː|n|ɑː}})'', means cold building or palace. The historical Tahakhana is located at the [[Gauḍa (region)]] in Firozpur area in the west of a big pond. It is 15 km from [[Chapai Nawabganj District]] in Shahbajpur Union at [[Shibganj Upazila, Chapai Nawabganj|Shibganj Upazila]].<ref>Salahuddin, Mohammad (6 March 2010)। "শাহ নিয়ামতুল্লাহ (রঃ) এর মাজার"। ''গৌড়বঙ্গ ও চাঁপাইনবাবগঞ্জ এর প্রাচীন নিদর্শন'' (2 সংস্করণ)। ঢাকা, বাংলাদেশ: জাতীয় সাহিত্য পরিষদ। পৃ: ১০১।</ref>
== History == [[Sultan of Bengal]], [[Shah Shuja (Mughal)|Shah Shuja]] founded this palace as a 'Temperature Control Unit' in honour of his [[Murshed]] Shah Syed Niyamatullah, mainly for comfort in winter. Son of [[Mughal Emperor]] [[Shah Jahan]], Shah Shuja founded this palace between 1619 and 1658 (or 1639–1660).<ref>Chakraborty, Rajinikanth (January 1999)। [http://50.30.47.15/ebook/bangla/Gourer_Itihas.pdf ''গৌড়ের ইতিহাস''] (PDF) (1 & 2 সংস্করণ)। Bankim Chatterjee Street, Calcutta 700 073: Dev's Publishing</ref> There is a saying that, when he came to meet with [[Murshed]] used the middle wider room.<ref>[http://shahabajpurup.chapainawabganj.gov.bd "সোনামসজিদ তোহাখানা মাজার শরিফ"]। মন্ত্রিপরিষদ বিভাগ, এটুআই, বিসিসি ও বেসিস</ref> A lot of unknown graves inside the 'Tahakhana Complex' considered as companions or Khadems of Shah Syed Niyamatullah. <gallery> File:Toha_Khana_(Kachari_bari)_Complex_of_Shah_Suja_03.jpg|Tahakhana carved artistry File:Toha_Khana_(Kachari_bari)_Complex_of_Shah_Suja_02.jpg|Tahakhana's ancient column </gallery>
== Structure == Ancient architecture like [[Gauḍa (region)|Gauḍa]] is rarely found except Tahakhana. Her ceiling and partition are coagulated on the beam by concrete casting. The Mosque and Tahakhana are on the lake name 'Dafe-ul-Balah'. Two stare cases are sank into the lake. Two more structures are on the north west side of the palace, nearer one is a three domed mosque and another one is one domed tomb with bolted veranda. All the buildings are founded by the same time for a specific purpose and considered as a complex unit. Main materiel of the building is brick. Black stone is used for the threshold and wooden vim used for plain roof. The building seems to be single storied from the west side but assumed double storied from the east side, extended by the rooms directly raised the archway from the lake. A [[Turkish bath|hammam]] is in the west of the building supplied water from an octagonal reservoir. A small family mosque is in the north and at its back side an open room which connected with an octagonal tower. This tower possibly used for [[contemplation]]. This octagonal tower balanced the complex. The palace is plastered and engraved by the crafts following [[Mughal architecture]].

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} '''Censorship of music''' refers to the practice of editing of [[music|musical works]] for various reasons, stemming from a wide variety of motivations, including moral, political, or religious reasons. Censorship can range from the complete government-enforced legal prohibition of a musical work, to private, voluntary removal of content when a musical work appears in a certain context.
==Motivations== ===Decency=== Songs are commonly edited for broadcast on [[radio]] and [[television]] to remove content that may be considered objectionable to an outlet's [[target audience]]—such as [[profanity]], or references to subjects such as [[sexual activity|sex]] and [[recreational drug|drug usage]]. This is typically done to comply with any relevant [[broadcast law]] or [[codes of conduct]], and to make the songs more marketable to a mainstream audience.<ref name=MIAcensdoubstandard/><ref name="npr-artofclean"/> Songs edited for content in this manner by are often referred to as a "[[clean version]]" or a "[[radio edit]]" (the latter also referring to songs that may be edited for length on radio airplay, and in the past, space limitations on 45 RPM [[vinyl record]]s).<ref name=cp-attentionspans>{{cite news|title=QuickHitz offers radio hit parade edited for short attention spans|url=http://www.theprovince.com/news/QuickHitz+offers+radio+parade+edited+short+attention+spans/10102495/story.html|accessdate=20 August 2014|agency=Canadian Press}}</ref><ref name="bbc-relaxban">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/3395823.stm|title=Banned on the run|website=BBC News|access-date=2017-06-30}}</ref> Common editing techniques include distorting vocals to obscure offending words (including muting, [[bleep censor|bleeping]], and [[backmasking]]), or replacing them with alternative lyrics.<ref name="guardian-sandm">{{cite web|last=Ewing|first=Tom|title=How pop is provoking the censors again|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2011/feb/09/rihanna-lyrics-censorship-radio-one|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=July 23, 2011}}</ref>
The amount of censorship required may vary between broadcasters, depending on [[standards and practices]] and their target audience; for example, [[Radio Disney]] imposes stricter content guidelines than conventional U.S. radio stations, as it primarily targets a youth audience and family listening.<ref name="bbc-relaxban"/><ref name="npr-artofclean">{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/11/08/454606994/the-art-of-the-clean-version|title=The Art Of The 'Clean Version'|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en}}</ref> By contrast, some radio stations may relegate unedited versions of tracks containing objectionable content to airplay during [[Watershed (broadcasting)|time periods deemed appropriate]], such as late-night hours.<ref name="bbc-relaxban"/> Joel Mullis, an Atlanta sound engineer who became well-known in the industry for his work on radio edits, noted that his job was often complicated by differing standards between broadcasters (such as [[BET]] and [[MTV]]), requiring different edits to meet their individual needs. Mullis' edit of the [[Ying Yang Twins]]' "[[Wait (The Whisper Song)]]" was constructed by splicing in vocals from other Ying Yang Twins songs, but Mullis eventually had to bring the group back to his studio after facing demands for additional edits.<ref name="npr-artofclean"/>
In some cases, a [[record label]] may choose to withhold a release entirely if they believe that its subject matter would be too controversial; [[Ice-T]] and [[Paris (rapper)|Paris]] both had [[gangsta rap]] albums withheld or indefinitely delayed by [[Warner Bros. Records]] over content concerns, with Ice-T's [[Home Invasion (album)|''Home Invasion'']] delayed due to the [[1992 Los Angeles riots]] and controversy over "[[Cop Killer (song)|Cop Killer]]"—a song by Ice-T's metal band [[Body Count (band)|Body Count]], and Paris's ''[[Sleeping with the Enemy (album)|Sleeping with the Enemy]]'' over its songs "[[George H. W. Bush|Bush]] Killa" and "Coffee, Doughnuts, & Death". [[Insane Clown Posse]] faced similar issues after they signed to [[Disney]]-owned [[Hollywood Records]]; despite compliance with the label's demands to censor specific songs and lyrics, ''[[The Great Milenko]]'' was recalled almost immediately after its release (but not before selling 18,000 copies out of 100,000 shipped). All three acts moved to different labels (including [[Priority Records]] and [[Island Records]]), which released their respective albums without objections.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/violent-j-breaks-down-insane-clown-posses-joker-card-lps-20150213/the-great-milenko-1997-20150213|title=Violent J Gives the Twisted Stories Behind ICP's Best LPs|website=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/1997/07/25/great-milenko/|title=The Great Milenko|date=1997-07-25|work=EW.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/09/controversial-rap-album-covers/paris-sleeping-with-the-enemy|title=A History of Scandalous Rap Album Covers: Paris, Sleeping with the Enemy (1992)|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref>
==== Notable examples ==== Multiple edits of [[CeeLo Green]]'s song "[[Fuck You (CeeLo Green song)|Fuck You]]" exist, including one which changed the titular lyric to "Forget You", and one which muted "fuck" without replacing it. Green also performed a [[Parody music|parody]] of the song about [[Fox News]] in an appearance on ''[[The Colbert Report]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2010/11/10/cee-lo-green-colbert-fox-news/|title=Cee-Lo Green swaps 'Fox News' for 'F--k You' on 'Colbert'|last=|first=|date=2010-11-10|work=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129454158|title=Cee Lo's Viral Hit: Blunt and Sweet|date=August 26, 2010|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=August 27, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/TECH/web/08/30/cee.lo.song.video/index.html|title=Cee Lo's YouTube hit you won't hear on radio|last=Brown|first=Damon|date=August 30, 2010|publisher=CNN|accessdate=August 30, 2010}}</ref> [[The Black Eyed Peas]] re-wrote "Let's Get Retarded"—a song from their album ''[[Elephunk]]'', as "[[Let's Get It Started]]" to serve as a promotional song for television coverage of the [[2004 NBA Playoffs]]. "Let's Get It Started" was subsequently released as a standalone single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1487022/black-eyed-peas-collaborating-with-darkness.jhtml|title=Black Eyed Peas To Make Their Own 'Walk This Way' — With The Darkness|date=14 May 2004|publisher=MTV|accessdate=11 December 2012}}</ref><ref name="billboard-jingles">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/events/super-bowl-xlvii/481117/10-hits-you-didnt-know-were-jingles|title=10 Hits You Didn't Know Were Jingles|website=Billboard|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}</ref> When performing his song "[[Power (Kanye West song)|Power]]" on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', [[Kanye West]] similarly replaced an entire verse, which contained profanities as well as lyrics directly criticising the program (such as "Fuck ''SNL'' and the whole cast") with newly-written lyrics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/kanye-west-power-lyrics-changed-saturday-night-live-performance-nbc-article-1.186295|title=Kanye uses 'Power' to change lyrics on 'SNL'|work=New York Daily News|access-date=2017-06-30|language=en}}</ref>
Songs containing potentially objectionable [[double entendre]]s or [[mondegreen]]s have also been subject to censorship. For example, the title and chorus of [[Britney Spears]]' single "[[If U Seek Amy]]" was intended to be misheard as "[[Sexual intercourse|F-U-C-K me]]"; her label issued a radio edit which changed the word "seek" to "see", in order to remove the wordplay.<ref name=nzherald>{{cite web | author=Guy Adams | title=Britney forced to rerecord 'sexually offensive' song | work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]| date=January 21, 2009 | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10552846 | accessdate=December 5, 2009}}</ref><ref name="mtvone">{{cite web | author=Gil Kaufman | title=Britney Spears' 'If U Seek Amy' Poses Censorship Problems For Radio | work=MTV.com |publisher=MTV Networks| date=February 12, 2009 | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1602458/20090109/spears_britney.jhtml | accessdate=December 16, 2009}}</ref> Similar concerns were raised by radio stations over The Black Eyed Peas' "[[Don't Phunk With My Heart]]" upon its release, as the word "phunk" (a deliberate misspelling of "funk") could be misinterpreted by listeners as sounding like the word "fuck".<ref name=mtvone/> [[Meghan Trainor]] recorded an alternate version of her debut single "[[All About That Bass]]" for Radio Disney and conservative [[adult contemporary]] stations, which removed the song's suggestive metaphors.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6266667/ac-radio-disney-are-all-about-that-edited-bass|title=AC, Radio Disney Are All About That (Edited) 'Bass'|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref><ref name="npr-artofclean"/>
Censorship of music is not limited to lyrical content; [[MTV]] edited the [[M.I.A. (rapper)|M.I.A.]] song "[[Paper Planes]]" to replace sounds of gunfire in its chorus with alternative sound effects, and remove a reference to cannabis. Similar sound edits occurred when M.I.A. performed the same song on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' (broadcast by then-corporate sibling [[CBS]]). M.I.A. subsequently criticized both MTV and ''Late Show'' for censoring her song.<ref name=MIAcensdoubstandard>{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Breihan |title=M.I.A. and the Double Standard of MTV Censorship|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/statusainthood/archives/2007/12/mia_and_the_dou.php|archivedate=February 19, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219004257/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/statusainthood/archives/2007/12/mia_and_the_dou.php|dead-url=yes|work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=December 18, 2007 |accessdate=October 25, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="MIAPlanesBlognytobserver">{{cite web | url=http://observer.com/2007/12/tube-surfing-mias-paper-planes/ | title=Tube Surfing: M.I.A.'s 'Paper Planes' | author=Gillian Reagen | work=[[The New York Observer]] | date=December 17, 2007 | accessdate=August 29, 2008 }}</ref>
==== Criticism ==== Some listeners have expressed dissatisfaction over the editing of songs for radio airplay, arguing that it compromises the artistic integrity of the original song, and encourage listeners to seek out alternative platforms that are not subject to such censorship, such as digital streaming. At the same time, edits are considered a necessary concession to receive the radio airplay that can influence a song's overall performance.<ref name="npr-artofclean"/> [[N.W.A.]]'s debut album ''[[Straight Outta Compton]]'' (which had attracted controversy for its song "[[Fuck tha Police]]") contains a song entitled "[[Express Yourself (N.W.A song)|Express Yourself]]", which criticizes radio censorship of music as inhibiting [[free expression]], and also criticizes other rappers for releasing inoffensive songs without profanity in order to receive radio airplay. Despite its themes, "Express Yourself" is the only song on the album to not contain profanities.<ref name="smh-expressyourself"/>
=== Sensitivity === Some songs may be pulled or downplayed by broadcasters if they are considered to be inappropriate to play in the aftermath of specific events. Following the [[September 11 attacks]], many broadcasters altered their music programming for these reasons,<ref>{{cite news | last = Strauss | first = Neil | title = The Pop Life; After the Horror, Radio Stations Pull Some Songs | work= [[The New York Times]]| date = November 19, 2001 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9906E2D9153BF93AA2575AC0A9679C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all| accessdate = August 4, 2008}}</ref> such as [[iHeartMedia|Clear Channel]], whose program directors compiled an [[2001 Clear Channel memorandum|internal list]] of "lyrically questionable" songs. The list included all [[Rage Against the Machine]] songs, as well as various songs with themes related to war, destruction, flight, or [[New York City]]. ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' noted several unusual choices on the list, including "[[Walk Like an Egyptian]]", two [[Cat Stevens]] songs (Stevens had converted to the [[Islamic faith]] and changed his name to Yusuf Islam), and [[John Lennon]]'s "explicitly pacifist anthem '[[Imagine (John Lennon song)|Imagine]]'".<ref>{{cite web|last=Truitt|first=Eliza|title=It's the End of the World as Clear Channel Knows It|work=[[Slate.com|Slate]]|date=September 17, 2001|url=http://slate.com/id/1008314/|accessdate=September 17, 2017| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071015200337/http://slate.com/id/1008314/| archivedate= October 15, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="austin-imagine">{{cite web | last = Bertin | first = Michael | title = Imagine: The music business in a post-911 world | work = | publisher = ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' | date = November 30, 2001 | url = http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2001-11-30/83800/ | accessdate = April 17, 2011 }}</ref>
Following the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'' disaster]] in February 2003, [[Mark Wills]]' "[[19 Somethin']]" was temporarily pulled by some radio stations as it contains a lyric referencing the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|''Challenger'' disaster]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=March 2003|title=Singles minded|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OA8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA55&lpg=PA55&dq=19+Somethin+pulled+columbia+disaster&source=bl&ots=0AH0eUw4-7&sig=3-MHmFYaADmGOfeiaIBV_wn0K4Y&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixmsaT0ObUAhUo34MKHbvADQ4Q6AEIODAE#v=onepage|journal=Billboard|volume=|pages=55|via=}}</ref> Also that month, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s then-upcoming music video for "[[American Life (song)|American Life]]" generated controversy due to its politicized and "unpatriotic" imagery (such as a [[fashion show]] featuring women dressed in military equipment, and a scene where the singer throws a [[grenade]]-shaped [[lighter]] to a [[George W. Bush]] lookalike to light his [[cigar]]), which were considered to be especially sensitive in the wake of the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq war]]. Due to the negative response, Madonna pulled the video prior to its planned premiere, as she did not want to "risk offending anyone who might misinterpret the meaning of this video".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2003/04/01/madonna-pulls-controversial-american-life-video/|title=Madonna pulls controversial ''American Life'' video|date=2003-04-01|work=EW.com|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/feb/10/antiwar.artsfeatures|title=Madonna takes swipe at Bush|last=Child|first=Ben|date=2003-02-10|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
In 2006, after [[Gary Glitter]] was convicted of child sexual abuse in [[Vietnam]], the [[National Football League]] banned the original recording of his song "[[Rock and Roll (Gary Glitter song)|Rock and Roll]]" (which was popularly played at U.S. sporting events)<ref name="SIV">{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1992/11/30/127693/the-vibes-of-victory-sports-fans-know-that-the-strains-of-rock-and-roll-part-ii-can-turn-chumps-to-champs|title=Sports fans know that the strains of 'Rock and Roll Part II' can turn chumps to champs|publisher=Time Inc.|author=Lisa Twyman Bessone|work=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref> from being played at its games. While the NFL still allowed a [[cover version]] of the song to be played, in 2012 the league instructed its teams to "avoid" playing the song entirely, following negative reception from British media over its continued use by the [[New England Patriots]], and the possibility it could be played during [[Super Bowl XLVI]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/legal-and-management/6273999/why-convicted-child-sex-offender-gary-glitters-hey|title=Why Convicted Child-Sex Offender Gary Glitter’s ‘Hey Song’ Is Still Getting Played|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/gary-glitter-10-1269123|title=NFL bosses ban Gary Glitter's 'Rock And Roll Part II' from the Super Bowl|date=2012-02-02|work=NME|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
Following [[Chris Brown]]'s alleged physical altercation with his then-girlfriend [[Rihanna]], various radio stations began to voluntarily pull Brown's music from their playlists as a condemnation of his actions.<ref name="mtv-willmore">{{cite web|title=Will More Radio Stations Stop Playing Chris Brown?|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1604845/will-more-radio-stations-stop-playing-chris-brown/|website=MTV.com|accessdate=30 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chris Brown's songs, TV appearances yanked from air|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1604786/chris-browns-songs-tv-appearances-yanked-from-air/|website=MTV.com|accessdate=30 June 2017}}</ref> In December 2013, [[HMV]] removed the entire catalogue of [[Lostprophets]] from its stores after the band's lead singer [[Ian Watkins (Lostprophets)|Ian Watkins]] was charged with thirteen sexual offences against children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/nov/29/lostprophets-removed-hmv-ian-watkins|title=Lostprophets' music removed from HMV following Ian Watkins trial|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2013-11-29|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== Legal issues === Songs and albums may, in some cases, be censored due to [[copyright]] problems (particularly related to [[Sampling (music)|sampling]]) or other legal issues. [[The KLF|The JAMs]] album ''[[1987 (What the Fuck Is Going On?)]]'' was withdrawn from distribution following complaints by [[ABBA]], whose music was sampled on the album without permission.<ref name=sweden87>[[James Brown (editor)|Brown, J.]], "Thank You For The Music", ''[[New Musical Express]]'', 17 October 1987.</ref> [[The Notorious B.I.G.]]'s album ''[[Ready to Die]]'' was similarly pulled following a lawsuit by [[Bridgeport Music]] over unauthorized samples.<ref name=bryantimes>{{cite news|agency=AP|title=Judge halts sales of Notorious B.I.G. album after jury finds song snippet used without permission|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VvkvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iUkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5587%2C2536180|accessdate=5 October 2013|newspaper=The Bryan Times|date=24 March 2006}}</ref><ref name=slate-sampletroll>{{cite web|last1=Wu|first1=Tim|title=Jay-Z Versus the Sample Troll: The shady one-man corporation that's destroying hip-hop|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2006/11/jayz_versus_the_sample_troll.html|website=Slate|accessdate=25 January 2016}}</ref>
By request of [[Atlantic Records]], parody musician [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] did not commercially release "[[You're Pitiful]]"—his parody of [[James Blunt]]'s song "[[You're Beautiful]]", even though Blunt himself had approved of the satire. It was subsequently released as a free single instead.<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url= https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5482774| title=Free 'Weird Al' Yankovic!|accessdate=September 22, 2006 |last=Thompson| first=Stephen|authorlink=Stephen Thompson (producer)|date=June 13, 2006|work=Mixed Signals|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]}}</ref>
== By country == === Australia === {{see also|Censorship in Australia}} The [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) and the Australian Music Retailers Association (AMRA) maintain a self-regulatory system known as the "Recorded Music Labelling Code of Practice", which utilizes a three-tier ratings system for objectionable content in music recordings. "Level 1" applies to content of a "moderate impact" (including "infrequent aggressive or strong coarse language; or moderate-impact references to drug use, violence, sexual activity or themes"), "Level 2" for "strong impact" ("frequent aggressive or strong coarse language", or strong references to drug use, violence, sexual activity or themes), and "Level 3" for "high impact" content (graphic and high-impact references to drug use, violence, sexual activity or themes). The Level 3 classification was introduced in March 2003, and requires purchasers to be over the age of 18. The code bans the distribution or sale of any recording with material that exceeds Level 3 classification, which includes content "which promote, incite, instruct or exploitatively or gratuitously depict drug abuse, cruelty, suicide, criminal or sexual violence, child abuse, incest, bestiality or any other revolting or abhorrent activity in a way that causes outrage or extreme disgust."<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2453315.stm |title= Australia plans CD 'censorship' |work= BBC News |date= 2002-11-12|access-date= 2018-03-22 |language= en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.aph.gov.au/parliamentary_business/committees/senate/legal_and_constitutional_affairs/completed_inquiries/2010-13/classificationboard/report/~/media/wopapub/senate/committee/legcon_ctte/completed_inquiries/2010-13/classification_board/report/c09.ashx |title= Inquiry |last=|first= |date= |website= Parliament of Australia |archive-url= |archive-date= |dead-url= |access-date= March 21, 2018}}</ref>
Australian customs law also bans the import of any product that "describe[s], depict[s], express[es] or otherwise deal[s] with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a way that they offend against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-singapore-pornography/singapore-pilot-fined-in-australia-for-laptop-child-porn-idUKSIN10289320080213|title=Singapore pilot fined in Australia for laptop child porn|agency=Reuters|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-GB}}</ref> In 2003, copies of an album by [[grindcore]] band Intense Hammer Rage were seized by the [[Australian Customs Service]], and the three band members were each fined [[Australian dollar|AUD$]]500 each for violating customs law. The violations centred upon the abhorrent subject matter of the album's artwork and printed lyrics; the albums had been manufactured in the United States by their record label, and imported into Australia for their distribution. The band criticized the seizure as being a dilution of [[freedom of speech]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/arts/music/stories/s885891.htm|title=Does Freedom of Speech Exist in Australia?|last=|first=|date=|website=ABC|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070129133906/http://www.abc.net.au/arts/music/stories/s885891.htm|archive-date=January 29, 2007|dead-url=|access-date=March 21, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2003-05-15/court-rules-cd-unfit-for-shelves/1854120|title=Court rules CD unfit for shelves|date=2003-05-15|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-AU}}</ref>
In May 1990, Nick Franklin, acting news director of the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]'s radio station [[Triple J]], was suspended by the ABC's management after having played a portion of [[N.W.A.]]'s song "[[Fuck tha Police]]". The song had received airplay on the station for several months, but ABC Radio head Malcom Long requested that the song be given a "rest"; in the offending segment, Franklin discussed the song's vulgar lyrics and subject matter. In protest of the suspension, Triple J staff went on strike, and the station [[stunting (broadcasting)|stunted]] by playing the N.W.A. song "Express Yourself" on a loop. The stunt ended after the ABC resolved the dispute and reinstated Long. The song was ultimately played 82 times in a row.<ref name="smh-expressyourself">{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/express-yourself-the-day-triple-j-played-the-same-nwa-song-82-times-in-a-row-20150902-gjdk0d.html|title=Express yourself: The day Triple J played the same N.W.A. song 82 times in a row|last=Casimir|first=Paul Chamberlin and Jon|date=2015-09-02|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref>
=== Canada === {{See also|Censorship in Canada}}
In Canada, content broadcast by radio and television is self-regulated under the code of ethics of the [[Canadian Association of Broadcasters]] by a group known as the [[Canadian Broadcast Standards Council]] (CBSC), which acts upon complaints submitted by the general public. The [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC) can intervene in more substantial cases.<ref name=":9" />
In 2011, the [[Atlantic Canada|Atlantic]] panel of the CBSC, in response to a complaint against [[CHOZ-FM]], ruled that the original version of [[Dire Straits]]' 1985 single, "[[Money for Nothing (song)|Money for Nothing]]" violated the ethics code, because of its use of the word "[[Faggot (slang)|faggot]]"—a homophobic slur. However, the CRTC called upon the CBSC to review the decision with a national panel, as it "elicited a strong public reaction and created uncertainty for private radio stations across the country." In particular, the CRTC asked the CBSC to consider the overall context of the slur in relation to the rest of the song, as well as how the word was used at the time of the song's release.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/CRTC+asks+review+Dire+Straits+song/4144591/story.html|title=CRTC asks for review of Dire Straits song ban|last=Abma|first=Derek|agency=Postmedia News|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en-ca}}</ref> The CBSC overturned the ruling; while panellists agreed that the slur was inappropriate, it was considered to be satirical and non-hateful in context. It was also noted that lead singer [[Mark Knopfler]] had substituted the word himself with alternatives (such as "queenie") during live performances, which was considered an admission that his original choice in words was in bad taste. The CBSC stated that it was up to individual stations whether or not they would play the unedited version.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
The ruling and controversy were ridiculed by critics; veteran Canadian radio personality [[Alan Cross]] commented that the controversy made Canada look "silly", remarking that "I talked to people from the U.S. and the U.K. and they were like, 'What's wrong with you people? Don't you get it? It's a joke. It's a satire. You didn't understand the context?" ''[[National Post]]'' columnist Chris Selley described the CBSC's new ruling as a "comedy classic" and "colossal waste of time", explaining that "it's one thing for a censor to decide whether something is legitimately artistic; it's another for it to declare whether or not it enjoys the art, as if it somehow mattered."<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/opinion/chris-selley-broadcast-standards-ruling-on-money-for-nothing-a-comedy-classic|title=Chris Selley: Broadcast Standards ruling on Money for Nothing a comedy classic|date=2011-09-01|work=National Post|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/canada-lifts-ban-on-dire-straits-money-for-nothing-20110901|title=Canada Lifts Ban on Dire Straits' 'Money for Nothing'|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref>
=== China === {{See also|Censorship in China}} During the rule of [[Mao Zedong]], "[[Yellow Music]]" became subject to criticism and censure, since the [[Communist Party of China]] saw Shanghai ''[[shidaiqu]]'' [[C-pop|pop music]]<ref name="shanghai">{{cite web |url=http://www.scmp.com/article/367361/shanghai-love |title=From Shanghai with love |date=31 December 2001 |work=South China Morning Post }}</ref> as indecent, and critics saw the sentiments of love songs as appealing only to the ''[[petite bourgeoisie]]''. The genre was also criticized over its connections to American [[jazz]] music, due to [[Anti-American sentiment]] from the [[Korean War]]. This resulted in many artists associated with shidaiqu, including [[Li Jinhui]] (who had been credited as a leading figure in the genre) and [[Chen Gexin]], being branded as "[[Right-wing politics|rightists]]" and persecuted. Shanghai pop was displaced by [[Political music in China|revolutionary music]] that promoted [[Maoism]] and other ideologies of the Communist Party. In 1966, [[Tian Han]]—writer of the Chinese national anthem "[[March of the Volunteers]]"—was imprisoned over his allegorical play ''Xie Yaohuan'' (which was critical of Mao's regime) in one of the opening salvos of the [[Cultural Revolution]]. His works were banned, leading to "[[The East Is Red (song)|The East is Red]]"—a song which glorified Mao's [[cult of personality]], being used as the ''de facto'' national anthem at this time.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wiQJmCxVICcC&pg=PA226#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Jazz Planet |editor= E. Taylor Atkins |page=226 |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year= 2004 |isbn= 978-1578066094 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Wagner |first=Rudolf G. |authorlink=Rudolf G. Wagner |title=The Contemporary Chinese Historical Drama: Four Studies |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7zFiHwkpo88C&pg=PA137 |year=1990 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-05954-2}}</ref><ref name="Jones">Jones. Andrew F. [2001] (2001). Yellow Music – CL: Media Culture and Colonial Modernity in the Chinese Jazz Age. Duke University Press. {{ISBN|0-8223-2694-9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=FMU2DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA456&lpg=PA456&dq=%22yellow+music%22+%22cultural+revolution%22&source=bl&ots=0YHKEPp_t7&sig=Oa62wTJdvgOmd9qgxjJnwHq18Zo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi4nO6qlZLaAhVI7oMKHSLuB9wQ6AEIeDAJ#v=onepage&q=%22yellow%20music%22%20%22cultural%20revolution%22&f=false|title=The Oxford Handbook of Music Censorship|last=Hall|first=Patricia|date=2017-09-27|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190850586|language=en}}</ref>
In contemporary times, musical works criticizing the Chinese government have also been subject to censure. [[Guns N' Roses]]' album ''[[Chinese Democracy]]'' was banned in the country, as its [[Chinese Democracy (song)|title track]] criticizes the Chinese government and contains references to the [[Falun Gong]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20081124/11883296 |title=內地封殺 GN'R 唱片 |language=Chinese |trans-title=Mainland blocked GN'R album |work=[[Apple Daily]] |location=China |publisher=[[Next Media]] |date=November 24, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626140806/http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20081124/11883296 |archivedate=June 26, 2015 |accessdate=June 26, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/chinese-media-calls-guns-n-roses-chinese-democracy-attack-article-1.334957|title=Chinese media calls Guns 'N Roses 'Chinese Democracy' an attack|author=Laura Johnston|date=November 24, 2008|accessdate=November 24, 2008|work=New York Daily News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/rock-album-an-attack-on-china-1033811.html|title=Rock album 'an attack on China'|accessdate=November 25, 2008|publisher=[[The Independent]] | location=London | first=Christopher | last=Bodeen | date=November 25, 2008}}</ref> The song "Legacy" on [[Pet Shop Boys]]' 2009 album ''[[Yes (Pet Shop Boys album)|Yes]]'' was changed to an instrumental for its Chinese release, as it contains the lyric "governments fall".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/dance/8329075/The-Most-Incredible-Thing-Pet-Shop-Boys-interview-for-the-ballet.html|title=The Most Incredible Thing: Pet Shop Boys interview for the ballet|last=Garratt|first=Sheryl|date=2011-02-17|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> In July 2017, it was reported that [[Justin Bieber]] had been banned from performing in the country, citing "a series of bad behaviours, both in his social life and during a previous performance in China, which caused discontent among the public."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/21/justin-bieber-banned-from-china-bad-behaviour-purify-discontent|title=Justin Bieber banned from China for 'bad behaviour'|last=Phillips|first=Tom|date=2017-07-21|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
China has historically condemned or banned any musician who publicly supports [[Tibetan independence movement|Tibetan independence]] or otherwise interacts with the [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]]; in 2008, [[Björk]] chanted "Tibet, Tibet" to the audience whilst performing "[[Declare Independence]]" during a concert in [[Shanghai]]. [[Zhou Heping]] stated that the song, which was not cleared by Chinese authorities, had caused "dissatisfaction among the broader Chinese audience". He described Björk's case as an isolated incident, and denied that the [[Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Culture]] was wanting to further restrict performances by [[Western world|Western]] acts in the country in response to the incident, since China wanted international musicians to perform there for the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7293605.stm|title=Western acts 'welcome' in China|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref> In 2013, German electronic music band [[Kraftwerk]] were denied [[travel visa|entry visa]]s over their intent to perform at a 1999 [[Free Tibet]] concert in [[Washington, D.C.]], which was cancelled due to inclement weather.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/mar/29/kraftwerk-denied-china-visa-tibet|title=Kraftwerk denied China visa over 1999 Free Tibet concert|last=Kaiman|first=Jonathan|date=2013-03-29|website=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> [[Maroon 5]] had concerts cancelled in the country after bandmember [[Jesse Carmichael]] posted a [[Twitter]] message for the Dalai Lama's 80th birthday, and [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] concerts in China were cancelled after lead singer [[Noel Gallagher]] performed at a Free Tibet concert in New York City. In 2016, the [[Publicity Department of the Communist Party of China|Publicity Department]] banned [[Lady Gaga]] after she posted a video of her meeting with the Dalai Lama prior to a conference in [[Indianapolis]].<ref name="guardian-m5ban">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/17/maroon-5-dalai-lama-tweet-may-have-led-to-cancelled-china-concerts|title=Maroon 5 Dalai Lama tweet may have led to cancelled China concerts|website=The Guardian|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="guardian-gagaban">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jun/28/china-lady-gaga-ban-list-hostile-foreign-forces-meeting-dalai-lama|title=China 'bans Lady Gaga' after Dalai Lama meeting|date=27 June 2016|work=The Guardian|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, [[South Korea]]n [[Music of South Korea|music]] and entertainment products became subject to a voluntary boycott in China, in retaliation for its stationing of a [[THAAD]] missile defence system to protect against attacks by [[North Korea]] (which has diplomatic ties with China).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/asia/china-ban-on-korea-culture-anniversary-1202537823/|title=China’s Blockade of Cultural Korea Marks Troublesome Anniversary|last=Kil|first=Sonia|date=2017-08-24|work=Variety|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> [[K-pop]] groups, as well as soprano [[Sumi Jo]], had performances cancelled in the country due to the sentiment. Share prices of [[S.M. Entertainment]] and [[YG Entertainment]] also fell, as South Korean entertainment companies had increasingly invested in China to take advantage of the [[Korean Wave]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/08/world/asia/china-korea-thaad.html|title=South Korean Missile Defense Deal Appears to Sour China’s Taste for K-Pop|last=Qin|first=Amy|date=2016-08-07|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-18|last2=Sang-Hun|first2=Choe|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/politics/7708963/china-blocks-korean-streaming-platforms-thaad|title=China Blocks Korean Entertainment on Streaming Platforms Over THAAD Row|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-09-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/23/world/asia/sumi-jo-soprano-maria-callas.html|title=3 Performances by Sumi Jo, Korean Soprano, Canceled in China|last=Qin|first=Amy|date=2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/biz/asia/china-confirms-ban-on-korean-content-talent-1201830391/|title=China Reportedly Bans Korean TV Content, Talent|last=Frater|first=Patrick|date=2016-08-04|work=Variety|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3045116|title=Thaad retaliation slashes Olympics visitors from China|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref> In November 2017, following the settlement of the THAAD dispute, Chinese media outlets began to ease their censure of K-pop content.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/hallyu-ban-over-korea-chinese-tv-music-program-content-song-wedding-livestream-19234|title=Is 'hallyu' ban over in China?|last=Maala|first=Jon|date=2017-11-03|work=International Business Times, Singapore Edition|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en}}</ref>
=== Israel === {{main|Censorship in Israel}} The German composers [[Richard Strauss]] and [[Richard Wagner]] have been considered controversial figures in Israel due to their associations with [[Nazi Germany]], in addition to Wagner's [[Wagner controversies#Antisemitism|displays of antisemitism]] towards the Jewish faith. Although the works of Strauss have since been performed in the country, there is still an [[Wagner controversies#Wagner's music in Israel|informal "ban" on the live performance of Wagner's works]], with concerts intending to do so having faced resistance and protests by Israelis. Despite this, local broadcasters such as radio stations have still played Wagner's music without controversy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1428634.stm|title=Barenboim breaks Wagner taboo|date=2001-07-08|access-date=2018-06-07|work=BBC News|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/05/tel-aviv-wagner-concert-cancelled|title=Tel Aviv Wagner concert cancelled after wave of protest|last=Sherwood|first=Harriet|date=2012-06-05|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-case-for-wagner-in-israel|title=The Case for Wagner in Israel|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/israelis-ready-to-sing-along-with-richard-strauss-but-not-wagner-1166534.html|title=Israelis ready to sing along with Richard Strauss but not Wagner|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== Malaysia === {{see also|Censorship in Malaysia}} In Malaysia, a Muslim-majority country, local law prohibits radio stations from playing songs that are "offensive to public feeling" or "violate good taste and decency". References to [[LGBT]] topics were censored from [[Lady Gaga]]'s "[[Born This Way (song)|Born This Way]]" by local radio stations because [[LGBT rights in Malaysia|homosexual acts]] are illegal in the country,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/malaysia/8403613/Lady-Gaga-takes-on-Malaysias-censors.html|title=Lady Gaga takes on Malaysia's censors|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/mar/18/lady-gaga-born-this-way-malaysia|title=Lady Gaga 'gay anthem' censored in Malaysia|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2011-03-18|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> while "[[Despacito]]" was pulled by Malaysia's state-owned radio stations following listener concerns over its "[[Haram|un-Islamic]]" lyrics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40665528|title=Despacito censored: Malaysia bans 'unsuitable' hit from state stations|date=2017-07-20|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-07-21/malaysia-ban-spanish-language-song-despacito-from-state-tv-radio/8731894|title=Malaysia bans Despacito over 'obscene lyrics'|date=2017-07-21|work=ABC News|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-AU}}</ref>
Concerts in Malaysia have also been subject to censorship to comply with the country's moral values; [[Avril Lavigne]] was instructed to not wear revealing clothing, jump, shout, or include any "negative elements" in a 2008 concert in Kuala Lumpur,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/aug/22/avril.lavigne.too.sexy.malaysia|title=Avril Lavigne 'too sexy' to perform in public|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2008-08-22|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Muslim citizens were initially banned from attending a Black Eyed Peas concert in 2009 due to its [[Guinness]] sponsorship, as alcohol is banned under [[Sharia law]] (the ban was lifted after Guinness agreed to cease advertising its involvement nor sell its products at the event),<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/sep/03/black-eyed-peas?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487|title=Ban on Muslims attending Black Eyed Peas concert reversed|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2009-09-03|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> and [[Adam Lambert]] agreed to make changes to a 2010 concert due to concerns that he would promote "[[gay culture]]".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/oct/12/adam-lambert-tone-down-act|title=Adam Lambert to tone down act for Malaysia concert|last=Martin|first=Dan|date=2010-10-12|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== North Korea === {{see also|Censorship in North Korea}} [[Music of North Korea]] is typically limited to state-sanctioned performers and ensembles, whose [[Propaganda in North Korea|propaganda]] music promotes the regime's ideologies and the [[North Korean cult of personality|cult of personality]]. Foreign music, and older North Korean music that do not meet the government's standards, is generally banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/7x9x8d/north-koreas-secret-weapon-is-terrible-synth-pop|title=North Korea's Secret Weapon Is Terrible Synth Pop|website=Vice|language=en-us|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref> In July 2015, it was reported that [[Kim-jong Un]] had issued a directive calling for inspectors to destroy music CDs and cassettes containing prohibited content, as well as adding additional songs to the blacklist (such as the entire soundtrack of the historical drama ''[[Im Kkeokjeong|Im Kkeok Jeong]]'').<ref name="guardian-nkmusicban">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/28/north-korea-music-bans-dissent|title=North Korea orders house-to-house searches to confiscate banned music|last=Min|first=Choi Song|date=2015-07-28|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-09-05|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6648329/north-korea-reportedly-orders-new-crackdown-on-banned-music|title=North Korea Reportedly Orders New Crackdown on Banned Music|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref>
Critics have argued that Kim Jong-un's regime was selectively becoming more open to having some [[Western world|Western]] influence over its culture, citing the inclusion of Western music (such as selections from the soundtrack of the film ''[[Rocky (film)|Rocky]]'', and the song "[[My Way]]") and imagery in the July 2012 debut performance of the [[Moranbong Band]]—an all-female military ensemble.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/articles/271e6e43-bf76-4517-89cf-64759c6a40d6|title=6 extraordinary facts about music in North Korea|work=BBC Music|date=2018-01-24|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=North Korea: Kim Jong-un entertained by Rocky soundtrack and My Way|work=Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9393212/North-Korea-Kim-Jong-un-entertained-by-Rocky-soundtrack-and-My-Way.html|language=en|accessdate=2017-09-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/07/still-my-way-or-the-highway-for-north-koreas-kim-analysts-say.html|title=It's still 'My Way' or the highway under North Korea's Kim|date=2012-07-13|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref> In July 2015, it was announced that Slovenian band [[Laibach (band)|Laibach]] would perform in [[Pyongyang]] as part of celebrations of the 70th anniversary of the end of Japanese rule. It was the first ever [[rock music]] concert in the country; the band stated that they planned to perform covers of traditional songs and selections from ''[[The Sound of Music]]''.<ref name="guardian-nkmusicban"/><ref name="nk-firstconcert">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/22/north-korea-laibach-pyongyang-concert|title=Laibach to play Sound of Music covers at Pyongyang's first rock concert|last=Hotham|first=Oliver|date=2015-07-22|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-09-05|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== South Korea === {{see also|Censorship in South Korea}}
Due to tense [[History of Japan–Korea relations|relations between Japan and South Korea]] following the end of [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese rule]], the Korean government imposed [[Censorship of Japanese media in South Korea|various restrictions]] on the importation of cultural works from other countries—laws ostensibly meant to target Japan.<ref name="ritsumei">中村知子 (Tomoko Nakamura) [http://www.ritsumei.ac.jp/acd/re/k-rsc/ras/04_publications/ria_ja/22_09.pdf "韓国における日本大衆文化統制" (Control of Japanese popular culture in Korea)] {{ja icon}}. [[Ritsumeikan University]]. March 2004.</ref> In September 1999, South Korea lifted its ban on live performances of Japanese music, but only in venues with a capacity smaller than 2000. In June 2000, it became legal to perform Japanese music in larger venues, and to sell music recordings originating from Japan. However, until January 2004, it remained illegal to sell recordings containing [[Japanese-language]] lyrics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2000/06/28/national/seoul-eases-ban-on-culture-from-japan/|title=Seoul eases ban on culture from Japan|date=2000-06-28|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}}</ref><ref name="IIST-japanban">{{Cite magazine | title = Ban Lifted on Japanese Popular Culture in South Korea | first = Hitoshi | last = Suzuki | magazine = IIST World Forum | publisher = Institute for International Studies and Training | date = 2004-03-15 | accessdate = 2016-07-05 | url = http://www.iist.or.jp/wf/magazine/0241/0241_E.html }}</ref><ref name="Demick">{{Cite web | title = South Korea Makes Way for Anime | last = Demick | first = Barbara | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 28 December 2003 | accessdate = 2016-07-05 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2003/dec/28/world/fg-japanculture28 }}</ref> It remains illegal to broadcast Japanese music over terrestrial radio and television in South Korea.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2011/09/01/2011090101778.html?news_Head1|title=日, 정치인까지 反한류 감정에 편승|work=Chosun|access-date=2018-06-28|language=ko}}</ref>
To appeal to the country's conservatism, television broadcasters have sometimes [[List of banned K-pop videos|pulled music videos from airplay]] for containing content they deem to be inappropriate, such as violent or sexually suggestive content. While Korea's three major television networks—[[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]], [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC]], and [[Seoul Broadcasting System|SBS]]—have all banned videos at some point, the [[public broadcasting|public broadcaster]] KBS is known for doing so more often due to its stricter regulations, which additionally forbid songs that encourage inappropriate behaviour (especially among youth), or contain references to brand names or Japanese words. This results in some songs, such as [[Psy (rapper)|Psy]]'s "[[Gentleman (Psy song)|Gentleman]]" (which was banned by KBS for a scene in which the singer kicks over a [[traffic cone]]) being banned only by KBS, but still receiving airplay by other networks.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/6531811/gain-hawwah-interview-religion-south-korea|title=Gain Goes In on New 'Hawwah' EP, Religion and South Korea's Conservative Music Industry|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20170614000718|title=G-Dragon, NCT 127 songs deemed unsuitable for KBS|work=The Korea Herald|date=2017-06-14|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/04/11/10-songs-banned-korean-broadcast|title=10 songs banned from Korean broadcast|website=SBS PopAsia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2014/04/03/crayon-pops-uh-ee-banned-for-shiny-japanese-word/|title=Crayon Pop’s ‘Uh-ee’ Banned for Shiny Japanese Word|last=Gale|first=Alastair|date=2014-04-03|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/01/25/kbs-bans-one-shinees-jonghyuns-new-songs|title=KBS bans one of SHINee's Jonghyun's new songs|website=SBS PopAsia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2013/04/18/south-korean-tv-network-bans-psys-video/|title=South Korean TV Network Bans Psy’s Video|last=Kwaak|first=Jeyup S.|date=2013-04-18|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref>
In 2010, the [[Supreme Court of South Korea]] ruled that it was illegal under the [[National Security Act (South Korea)|National Security Act]] to possess music that praises North Korea, even if instrumental, as it constitutes an "enemy-benefiting expression".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/songs-praising-north-korea-breach-law-20101108-17kbj.html|title=Songs praising North Korea breach law|date=2010-11-08|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === [[File:Sex_Pistols_in_Paradiso.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Sex Pistols]]' "[[God Save the Queen (Sex Pistols song)|God Save the Queen]]" was banned by radio stations, and allegedly suppressed from being the number-one song in the UK, due to its criticism of the British government and monarchy.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" />]] {{See also|Censorship in the United Kingdom}} The telecommunications regulator [[Ofcom]] has the power to reprimand broadcasters for playing songs and music videos that breach its guidelines on harmful or offensive content pre-watershed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-15525591|title=Ofcom warns radio broadcasters over explicit lyrics|date=2011-10-31|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/may/09/rihanna-sm-video-too-explicit-for-daytime-broadcast?INTCMP=SRCH|title=Rihanna's S&M video 'too explicit for daytime broadcast'|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=2011-05-09|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The [[British Phonographic Industry]] (BPI) adopted the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) [[Parental Advisory|Parental Advisory label]] program; in July 2011, the BPI published guidance for use of the logo on digital streaming platforms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jun/02/parental-warnings-online-music|title=Parental warnings to be introduced for online music|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=2011-06-02|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
The [[BBC]] was historically known for [[List of songs banned by the BBC|censoring]] various songs from being played on its [[BBC Radio|radio]] and [[BBC Television|television]] stations; from the 1930s through 1960s, the BBC had banned songs such as "[[Hold My Hand (1953 song)|Hold My Hand]]" for its religious references, pop arrangements of classical tunes (though barring "[[Sabre Dance]]" because it was "not a well-loved classic whose perversion we would be encouraging"), and during [[World War II]], songs that were "slushy in sentiment", such as "[[I'll Be Home for Christmas]]", due to concerns that it would affect the morale of soldiers. "[[Mack the Knife]]" was also banned from airplay outside of ''[[The Threepenny Opera]]'', as the BBC felt it would be offensive outside of the context of the play.<ref name="Unfit for aunties">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/unfit-for-aunties-airwaves-the-artists-censored-by-the-bbc-765106.html|title=Unfit for Auntie's airwaves: The artists censored by the BBC|date=14 December 2007|work=[[The Independent]]|location=London|accessdate=17 December 2008}}</ref> [[The Kinks]]' "[[Lola (song)|Lola]]" was briefly banned under the BBC's anti-[[product placement]] rules, as its lyrics contain references to the brand name [[Coca-Cola]]. In the midst of an American tour, lead singer [[Ray Davies]] flew back to [[London]] to re-record the offending lyric as "cherry cola".<ref name="New Zealand Herald-bbc">{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/radio-industry/news/article.cfm?c_id=295&objectid=10483279|title=Banning songs not a rare occurrence for the BBC|last=|first=|date=19 December 2007|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=15 October 2011|location=Auckland}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RICQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151&dq=ray+davies+cherry+cola&source=bl&ots=S6Kt3TJHP_&sig=uXTjv1fCZSUrfTU002NGXZjyJ9Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nLyNU77WGo7NsQSN0oHIBQ&ved=0CHsQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=ray%20davies%20cherry%20cola&f=false|title=Ray Davies: Not Like Everybody Else|last=Kitts|first=Thomas M.|date=2008-01-23|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135867959|language=en}}</ref>
